prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Arguments rejected by the Panel—Pendency of motions in transferor court

para.paratext: The Panel has regularly rejected arguments that transfer is inappropriate because there are motions pending before the transferor court.[1] In one case, however, the Panel did decline to order transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 where motions to transfer the cases for all purposes under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) were pending in the transferor court.[2] In other cases the Panel has specifically declined to refuse to transfer on this ground, although it has considered this factor in determining the timing of a transfer decision.[3] The Panel has rejected this argument even where the pending motion would, if granted, remove the only common issues from the cases,[4] or would destroy federal jurisdiction.[5] The rejection of this argument is consistent with the recognition that transferee courts have full authority to decide any such motions, and the Panel often cites as authority an early decision recognizing the plenary jurisdiction of transferee courts.[6] The Panel frequently points out that a motion for remand can be presented to the transferee judge.[7] By a stronger argument, the mere fact a party seeks to avoid transfer by the argument that there are legal issues to be raised by motion will face the probable conclusion that these matters can be raised before and decided by the transferee judge.[8]

The pendency of motions before the transferor court may affect, however, the timing of the Panel's action. In one case the Panel determined to allow the transferor court to decide pending motions before ruling on the transfer motion.[9] In another case the Panel stayed action to await progress in settlement of actions pending in the transferor courts or transferred and stayed pending decision.[10] The panel has also declined to delay transfer in these situations.[11]

In order for the pendency of a motion to have any impact on the Panel decision, it must probably be a motion that the transferor court is in an especially good position to decide. This may be particularly likely if the motion had been argued and was under advisement at the time the Panel proceedings were initiated. Conversely, if the motion is one that presents issues of federal law presumably equally familiar to any federal judge, this argument is very unlikely to be persuasive, as the transferee judge can easily decide it.[12] The pendency of the motions is likely to affect the timing decision alone; it will not prevent ultimate transfer unless the decision on the motion disposes of the case or cases to be transferred. Timing of the Panel decisions is discussed in greater detail in § 5:54.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Prudential Ins. Co. of America SGLI/VGLI Contract Litigation, 763 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011); In re: Capital One Bank Credit Card Interest Rate Hike Litigation, 716 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2010); In re: DIRECTV, Inc., Early Cancellation Fee Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Stand 'n Seal Products, 469 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer ordered despited pendency of motion for remand); In re Farmers Ins. Exchange Claims Representatives' Overtime Pay Litigation, 196 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Waste Management, Inc., Securities Litigation, 177 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2001); In re StarLink Corn Products Liability Litigation, 152 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2001); In re Asbestos Products Liability Litigation (No. VI), 1996 WL 143826 (J.P.M.L. 1996).
See In re Deering Milliken Patent, 328 F. Supp. 504 (J.P.M.L. 1970).

See, e.g., In re Duarte, California Air Crash Disaster on June 6, 1971, 354 F. Supp. 278 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Kaehni Patent, 311 F. Supp. 1342, 1344 (J.P.M.L. 1970). The timing of transfer decisions is discussed in § 5:54.
See In re REA Express, Inc., Private Treble Damage Antitrust Litigation, 386 F. Supp. 1406, 1407 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
See, e.g., In re Stand 'n Seal Products, 469 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation, 793 F. Supp. 1098, 1101 (J.P.M.L. 1992).

In re Ivy, 901 F.2d 7 (2d Cir. 1990) (transferee court has authority to decide pending jurisdictional matters); see also In re Pineapple Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Prudential Ins. Co. of America Sales Practices Litigation, 170 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2001). Ivy has been cited frequently by the Panel. See, e.g., In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Waste Management, Inc., Securities Litigation, 177 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2001); In re StarLink Corn Products Liability Litigation, 152 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2001).

See, e.g., In re Ford Motor Co. Speed Control Deactivation Switch Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Kugel Mesh Hernia Patch Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Reciprocal of America (ROA) Sales Practices Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Bausch & Lomb Inc. Contact Lens Solution Products Liability Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Gadolinium Contrast Dyes Products Liability Litigation, 559 F. Supp. 2d 1402 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Conagra Peanut Butter Products Liability Litigation, 559 F. Supp. 2d 1401 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Avandia Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 559 F. Supp. 2d 1400 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re McDonald's French Fries Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Avandia Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 543 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Baycol Products Liability Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Guidant Corp. Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Pharmaceutical Industry Average Wholesale Price Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., Tires Products Liability Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2008). The Panel in these cases almost invariably cites In re Ivy, 901 F.2d 7 (2d Cir. 1990), and In re Prudential Ins. Co. of America Sales Practices Litigation, 170 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2001), as authority for this proposition.

See In re Rye Select Broad Market Prime Fund Securities & Employee Retirement Income Sec. Act (ERISA) Litigation, 648 F. Supp. 2d 1385 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (transferee court can decide union's role favoring arbitration of matter and accounting firm assertion of its claims in Madoff-related litigation).
See In re Kaehni Patent, 311 F. Supp. 1342, 1344 (J.P.M.L. 1970).

See, e.g., In re Admission Tickets, 302 F. Supp. 1339, 1340 (J.P.M.L. 1969). See also In re: Power Balance, LLC, Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 777 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2011) (proposed settlement pending; transfer denied).
In re Novastar Home Mortgage Inc. Mortgage Lending Practices Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (Panel declines to defer transfer until pending motion is decided).
See, e.g., In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (motion to remand to state court).
